history.content:
Hey engineers and computer scientists,

 

My name is Thanh (Junior EECS) and I am a part of a team that is currently designing a nationwide, university-level flight simulation competition with students and faculty from UC Berkeley, UC San Diego, and USC as part of the NASA Artemis Student Challenge. 

 

Project LEAPFROG is both an earth-based in-flight and computer simulation lunar lander challenge. The physical lander features a gimbaled jet engine providing thrust vector control and a cold gas attitude control system. Flight patterns are preprogrammed before take-off. The computer-based simulation uses PX4, ROS, and Gazebo software.

 

In response to COVID-19, however, we are planning to launch only our computer-based simulation competition this summer. As such, we are currently reaching out to multiple student organizations across the UC Berkeley campus to “beta test” our simulation. Ideally, these test teams should have experience in controls theory as well as familiarity with software such as PX4, ROS, and Gazebo.

 

This is a wonderful opportunity to apply the skills you learned in EE 128 or EECS 106a! Perks include callouts in associated news stories in our communications with NASA, and also wonderful resume building experience. Please email me back at thanhtran@berkeley.edu so we can set up a Zoom meeting to discuss this opportunity further, or if you have any questions. Thank you!

Note: interested individuals are also certainly welcome!
history.subject: NASA LEAPFROG Looking for Simulation Beta Testers
